page.title: 11Woodvale Airfield, Ainsdale
page.content: The small{RAF}base at Woodvale lies between the Liverpool to Southport railway and the A565. Trains, planes and cars travel in close proximity. Once an asparagus farm, Woodvale has been an RAF base since 1943, when it was a Spitfire fighter base in World War Two. Air-raid shelters remain. Now, its main purpose is to train pilots for the RAF. It is run by 11 officers and 50 civilians. There are three runways and several camouflaged buildings, including the Officers' Mess and Liverpool Squadron HQ. There are two hangars and a small control tower. Woodvale is used by two{flying clubs and three RAF squadrons. The RAF use 'Chipmunk' and 'Bulldog' planes. The flying clubs use Cessna planes and charge Â£30.78 for an hour's tuition.
